unit.title: Freeway & Expressway Driving
objectives: Enter, merge, and exit freeways safely using proper scanning and signaling.
Manage speed and space at high speeds, including safe following distances and lane discipline.
Perform lane changes with mirror, signal, head-checks; choose lanes based on traffic flow and destination.
Handle breakdowns, debris, and emergencies; apply California Move Over law.
Navigate carpool/HOV and express/toll lanes, and respond to ramp meters.

sections.title: On-Ramps, Merging & Lane Choice
sections.summary: Build smooth, predictable freeway entries and select the correct lane for your route.

lessons.title: Ramp Types, Acceleration Lanes & Ramp Meters

content.text: Freeway ramps include loop, directional, and cloverleaf designs. Use the acceleration lane to reach a speed that matches freeway traffic.
Ramp meters (red/green lights) release vehicles in short intervals to reduce merging conflicts. Obey posted signals and signs.

items: Signal early; check mirrors and blind spots.
Use the entire acceleration lane to match traffic speed.
Yield to freeway traffic—merging drivers must adjust.

content.text: Merge into the first safe gap without forcing others to brake hard. Maintain steady acceleration and avoid stopping on the ramp unless signed.

items: Right lanes: entering/exiting traffic—more turbulence.
Middle lanes: through travel—often the steadiest flow.
Left lanes: passing and faster flow—use only when appropriate.

sections.title: Speed, Space & Following Distance
sections.summary: Create time and space cushions to manage risk at freeway speeds.

content.text: Obey posted maximums and drive a speed that is reasonable for conditions. Flow speed can inform—but never justify—unsafe speeds.

items: Increase distance as speed increases.
Slow for weather, congestion, or road work.
Avoid blocking fast lanes; keep right except to pass.

content.text: Use at least a 3–4 second following distance in ideal conditions; add time for rain, darkness, heavy loads, or when following large trucks.

items: Count seconds from when the vehicle ahead passes a fixed point.
Maintain side space by avoiding blind spots.
Double your space cushion in poor conditions.

sections.title: Lane Changes, Passing & Exiting
sections.summary: Change lanes and exit smoothly using proper signals, checks, and timing.

content.text: Follow the mirror–signal–head check routine. Avoid lingering next to other vehicles and never cut off a vehicle in the fast lane.

items: Use turn signals for every lane change.
Check mirrors and over-the-shoulder blind spots.
Complete the maneuver smoothly, then cancel the signal.

content.text: Signal and move to the exit lane early. Reduce speed only after entering the deceleration lane; never brake abruptly in a travel lane.

items: If you miss an exit, continue to the next—never back up.
Stay out of the gore area (painted triangle near exits).
Watch for last‑second cutters; maintain your space.

sections.title: Breakdowns, HOV/Express Lanes & Move Over
sections.summary: Handle roadside emergencies and special lane rules.

content.text: If your vehicle fails, signal right, exit if possible, or steer fully onto the shoulder. Use hazard lights and stay behind a barrier if available.

items: Use reflective triangles/flares only if safe.
Call for roadside assistance; stay clear of traffic.
If stuck in a live lane, stay belted and call 911.

content.text: Carpool lanes have occupancy or vehicle-type rules; express lanes may require transponders or tolls. Enter/exit only where permitted.

items: Obey posted occupancy and hours.
Cross only where lane markings allow.
Move Over: slow or change lanes for stopped emergency/roadside workers when safe.
